Blog.post: Why don’t you clarify the rules? – you may think. But once you indicate the rules clearly, it will arouse opposition from those who are against the rule. Japanese people usually think any conflict is of no benefit. When it comes to democratic process, it must be more desirable to discuss about the rule and try to reach agreement. But some Japanese probably regard this process as waste of time and say, “we’ve done well without them.” Certainly, it seems that we’ve done well, but how about hereafter? The number of foreigners living in Japan continues increasing. We will have been left them out?

Why are there many tacit rules in Japan? The principal factor is, I think, homogeneity of Japanese or Japan. Japanese people don’t like behaving in different manner, for they want to avoid making themselves conspicuous. In a train, for instance, you can always see Japanese people sitting in the same polite manner. In addition, those who live in Japan are mostly Japanese. ( it's anything but tautology.) Race homogeneity is the important feature of Japan. In short, Japanese want to do as others do, and there are only Japanese in Japan. Therefore tacit rules have worked well. It’s the rules which work only among similar members.

You have a plenty of opportunities to feel "tacit rules" in Japan. For example, you can see people standing on the left side on every escalator in Tokyo though there are no rule that you must stand on the left. Sometimes you can also see a foreigner standing on the right side of an escalator and others behind him trip on and frown at him. They think he stands on the wrong side.

I'm a local government officer of urlLink Tokyo Metropolitan Government(T.M.G.) . I'm engaged on government procurement. Let me talk about my career in detail now. T.M.G. buys hundreds of goods, services, costruction and construction-related services each year. Individual agencies of T.M.G. are authorized to conduct procurements for goods and services valued within certain prices. All higher-valued procuresses for goods are conducted by Bureau of Finance, which I belong to, on behalf of the other agencies. I intermediate between agencies and vendors by appropriate procedure - usually bid.
